abstract.heading: Background
abstract.text: Leukotriene receptor antagonists are a new class of drug that were initially identified for use in asthma. As they have an effect on neutrophil mediated inflammation, they may be of benefit in bronchiectasis.

abstract.heading: Objectives
abstract.text: To determine whether leukotriene receptor antagonists have any additive benefit over and above conventional treatment for bronchiectasis (usually consisting of antibiotics and postural drainage).

abstract.heading: Search methods
abstract.text: The Cochrane Airways Group Specialised Regsiter of trials and CENTRAL were searched up to May 2011.

abstract.heading: Selection criteria
abstract.text: Only randomised, controlled trials were considered

abstract.heading: Data collection and analysis
abstract.text: The results of searches were analysed by both authors

abstract.heading: Main results
abstract.text: No randomised, controlled trials were identified. The latest search was in May 2011.

abstract.heading: Authors' conclusions
abstract.text: Further research is required to establish any benefit from the use of leukotriene antagonists in bronchiectasis.

pls_title: Leukotriene receptor antagonists for non-cystic fibrosis bronchiectasis
pls: Leukotriene receptor antagonists are a new class of drug which may have an anti-inflammatory action in some patients with asthma. In theory they may also be of benefit in bronchiectasis, but no randomised controlled trials have yet been reported so it is not possible to make a recommendation about their use in this condition.
